sentence.text: Patient 1 is a 10-year-old boy and the first child to non-consanguineous Argentinian parents.
Prenatal ultrasound at 16 weeks’ gestation showed a cystic hygroma.
He was born after term following an uncomplicated pregnancy, with a birth weight of 4.25 kg (>97th centile), a birth length of 50 cm (50th centile) and a head circumference of 35 cm (50th centile).

His craniofacial features are typical of CED, namely: long face, high forehead with frontal bossing, telecanthus, epicanthic folds bilaterally, a broad nasal bridge, long philtrum, everted lower lip, retrognathia, and prominent, low-set ears.
Notably, he did not have craniosynostosis.
Additional clinical features include small teeth, fine, sparse hair, a short neck with excess skin folds, and brachysyndactyly with bilateral fifth finger clinodactyly.
In the first year of life, he had frequent respiratory infections.
Hepatomegaly was first diagnosed when he was 8 months old and the subsequent liver biopsy showed mild chronic hepatitis in cirrhotic evolution.
He had a normal male karyotype (46,XY) and ophthalmological examination showed no evidence of retinal dystrophy.
Blood tests at the age of 9 years revealed elevated creatinine values.
Ultrasound scans showed a small liver, splenomegaly, and normal-sized kidneys.
At the age of 9 years and 7 months, his growth and mental and motor development are normal.
